narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: This class was taught as a live virtual lecture. Professor Cai used his iPad as a whiteboard to write down notes, which would be saved and posted on the course website (along with a recording of the lecture).
Lectures were recorded.
Recorded lecture was also an option.
Piazza and office hours on zoom

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Some classical game theory, but primarily auction theory/mechanism design, and some algorithms.

In this class, I learned a lot of information about the new developments in the intersection of game theory and computation. I learned various proofs and theories on finding Nash Equilibria (and the existence of Nash Equilibria), setting up auctions, forming stable matchings, solving for the price of anarchy, among other neat economic topics. It was really exciting to see how powerful these algorithms are in representing game theory and human interaction. In addition, I learned how to formulate my own algorithms and solve these problems quantitatively and critically. This class had a lot of applications, and it was clear to me that implementing algorithms into game theory and economic principles is a new and exciting field.
Understanding of some special topics in economics and how they relate to computer science.

The stuff we learned was really cool. We began with the basics of game theory and online learning, then pivoted to ideas about voting systems, and in general mechanism design. We spent a good amount of time developing the theory of auctions and also looked at the price of anarchy and price of stability. Finally, we did some cake cutting.
Zero-sum games, online learning, Nash equilibrium, matching markets, voting systems, auction theory, selfish routing

The course provides a survey of key topics in algorithmic game theory and mechanism design. The first unit focuses on two-player zero sum games, how to capture such games using LPs and duality, and how this framework yields a (non-analytic) proof of Von Neumann's Minmax Theorem. The second unit deals with no-regret learning (and uses the existence of such learning algorithms to provide an alternative proof of the Minmax Theorem). The third unit proves Nash's Theorem and discusses the computational complexity of computing Nash Equilibria. The fourth unit deals with social choice theory and (welfare-optimal and revenue-optimal) mechanism design. The course concludes with an overview of some other topics in the field of economics and computation, such as price of anarchy and fair division.
General techniques and areas of Algorithmic Game Theory.
matching, bidding algorithms.

In-depth Mathematical and theoretical applications of game theory and computational practices in economics, focusing on concepts like auctions, search algorithms, and applications of linear programming.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Cai is a great lecture who gives clear proofs and is engaging. The material itself is also complex but really interesting and beautiful. The class had really tough problem sets, which often hurt my head and forced me to think critically and dive deeper into the material. However, the toughness and rarity of the problem sets (only 3 problem sets) made the nights before the problem sets due extremely stressful. This class could have benefited from shorter assignments during the weeks where there wasn't a problem set assigned, ensuring that we understood the material and introducing the mechanisms necessary for the tough problem sets.

The topic list felt somewhat incohesive. In particular, some topics we discussed were barely algorithmic (e.g. voting problems), and others, like auction theory, have very substantial overlap with normal economics. A more specific topics list would have been very helpful in deciding whether to take the course.

Strengths: This is basically where Professor Cai's research is, so he knows exactly what he is doing and lectures very clearly. He's good at conveying intuition behind results, which at least in my opinion is often more valuable than knowing the proof. I also just found the topics to be extremely interesting, especially mechanism design; there's lots of practical application here so you feel like the theory you're learning is doing something useful. There are only three problem sets, and even though they are challenging, I was never bored trying to figure out a problem.

Weaknesses: The only possible weakness I could think of is that we sometimes covered some topics at a pretty shallow level, and I felt like I would have preferred not covering something and instead delving deeper into some areas that we spend more time on.

Strengths of the course are its breadth of topics and the depth at which they are explored. This course provides an excellent starting point for students interested in working on problems in the field.
The course is much more practical in class are much more theoretical in the problem sets and I wish there was a way to reconcile the two a bit more.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought this class actually benefited a lot from recording the lectures. There was always so much information to parse through each lecture that often watching the lecture once wasn't enough. Keeping the recorded lectures and notes on Canvas facilitated better, more reinforced learning.
Attending/watching lectures and asking questions in office hours were sufficient to facilitate learning of the material.

Do you lecture notes could have contained a bit more context because when reviewing them, it was quite necessary for me to watch the whole lecture over again to understand why certain parts of the notes were where they were.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Yes. If you want to learn about auctions and mechanism design, definitely take this class. ECON 351 does not cover this stuff at all essentially. 
The algorithms prerequisite is not important per se, but primarily there for mathematical maturity purposes in my opinion. A strong comfort level with probability theory is quite important however, it's at the heart of many of the arguments being made.

Yes, I would recommend this course to students who are interested at the intersection of computing and economics. This class was a quantitative challenge, but one that bridged the gap between the two subjects succinctly. The material spurs a lot of research questions that can hopefully be solved in the near future. At the end of the day, Economics and Computation gave me a better appreciation for the power of computing in other quantitative fields. This class is well suited for computer science and economics majors.

Yes, if you are at all interested in economics or computer science. Although, there's not as much algorithm designing here (we cover some like Gale-Shipley, Top trading cycle, etc.) but that's kind of expected. Most of the classes are proofs, so you should be comfortable with them. In terms of math background, it says MATH 241 is a prerequisite but it's mostly just expected value calculations and you never need anything terribly fancy, even on the homework. In general, I would recommend this course to anyone who's used to proofs. There's really nothing else quite like it.

I would highly recommend this course to a student who is interested in theoretical computer science/economics. For students in economics, the course provides alternative approaches to some classical results, as well as some surprising results that seem difficult to prove without tools used in theoretical computer science, such as LP duality. For students in computer science, the course provides many interesting applications of the concepts taught in CPSC 365/366. Moreover, the theory developed in this course is both useful in practical settings, e.g., online ad auctions, as well as in theoretical/academic settings.

Absolutely! The material we covered was in-depth enough to be interesting and significant without being overwhelming, and Prof. Cai is a great instructor. The psets were always tough but fair, and we had a while to do them.
highly recommend if you are interested in the topics.
I would recommend this course to individuals who have to take it as part of their major, but not for an individual looking to take a course that will enrich their economic knowledge.
